importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date when former French President Nicolas Sarkozy entered La Santé prison to begin serving a 5-year sentence for criminal conspiracy in connection with his 2007 campaign financing from Libya, marking a historic moment as the first ex-leader of modern France to be imprisoned.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2005 to 2007 is central to the criminal conspiracy charge, during which Sarkozy, serving as interior minister and presidential candidate, allegedly used his position to finance his campaign with funds from Libya under Moammar Gadhafi's regime.

keyTakeAways: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy is serving a 5-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy to finance his 2007 election campaign with funds from Libya.
Sarkozy is the first ex-leader of modern France to be imprisoned, making this event historically significant.
He was sentenced after a Paris court ruled that the offense seriously disrupted public order, warranting immediate incarceration without awaiting an appeal.
Sarkozy is being held in solitary confinement at the notorious La Santé prison, due to security concerns, and will not see other inmates.
Sarkozy claims he is innocent and accuses political and foreign actors linked to Libya of orchestrating a 'plot' against him.
His lawyers have filed an immediate request for release, and he is entitled to one outdoor hour per day and three family visits per week.
He intends to bring three books to prison, including Alexandre Dumas’ 'The Count of Monte Cristo' and a biography of Jesus Christ.
Sarkozy has sparked a national outpouring of public support, with supporters chanting 'Courage Nicolas, come back soon' and expressing outrage at what they see as a judicial injustice.
France’s top magistrate, Rémy Heitz, has warned that political figures such as President Emmanuel Macron, who visited Sarkozy, could threaten judicial independence by intervening in the case.
President Emmanuel Macron did not comment directly on the verdict but acknowledged the emotional impact on the public and stressed the need for judicial independence.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy began serving a five-year prison sentence on October 21, 2025, after being convicted of criminal conspiracy to finance his 2007 election campaign with funds from Libya, led by Moammar Gadhafi. This makes him the first ex-leader of modern France to be imprisoned. Sarkozy, 70, was held in solitary confinement at the notorious La Santé prison, where he will not see other inmates. His lawyers contest the conviction and the decision to incarcerate him immediately, filing a request for release. Despite widespread public support, including chants from supporters outside his home, Sarkozy maintains he is innocent and accuses political actors of a conspiracy. The case has drawn significant political attention, with President Emmanuel Macron hosting Sarkozy and France’s top magistrate, Rémy Heitz, warning that political interference could undermine judicial independence.
title: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy Begins 5-Year Prison Sentence for Campaign Finance Conspiracy
